content:
HTML has two types of lists, ordered and unordered. ## Ordered Lists An ordered list is a set of numbered items.
Example Result 
<ol>
    <li>Step 1 </li>
    <li>Step 2 </li>
    <li>Step 3 </li>
</ol>
An ordered list element has the tag `
    ` . This is an abbreviation for Ordered List. Each item in the list is marked by a list item element `
  1. `. This is an abbreviation for List Item. The list item element is a child element, which means that it goes inside of its parent element, the ordered list (`
      `). Making an ordered list has two steps: making the list and adding the list items. To make the ordered list, write the ordered list tags `
      `. Next, add your list items **inside** the ordered list tags. To make each list item, use the list item tags `
      2. ` and write the list item inside the tags. It can be helpful to indent your`
    2. ` tags so it's clear they are contained in the `
        ` tag. ## Unordered Lists An unordered list is a set of bulleted items.
        Example Result 
        <ul>
    <li>Red </li>
    <li>Green </li>
    <li>Blue</li>
</ul>
        An unordered list element has the tag `
          ` . This is an abbreviation for Unordered List. Each item in the list is marked by a list item element `
        • `. This is an abbreviation for List Item. The list item element is a child element, which means that it goes inside of its parent element, the unordered list (`
            `). Making an unordered list has two steps: making the list and adding the list items. To make the unordered list, write the unordered list tags `
            `. Next, add your list items **inside** the unordered list tags. To make each list item, use the list item tags `
            • ` and write the list item inside the tags. It can be helpful to indent your `` tags so it's clear they are contained in the `
              ` tag. ## Additional Structure Information ## List Item Content **W3 Schools Links** * [<li>](https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_li.asp) * [<ul>](https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_ul.asp) * [<ol>](https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_ol.asp)
